title: 306-D
statement: D. Polygontime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstdinoutputstdoutPolycarpus loves convex polygons, especially if all their angles are the same and all their sides are different. Draw for him any such polygon with the given number of vertexes.InputThe input contains a single integern(3 ≤n≤ 100) — the number of the polygon vertexes.OutputPrintnlines, containing the coordinates of the vertexes of then-gon "xiyi" in the counter clockwise order. The coordinates of the vertexes shouldn't exceed106in their absolute value. The side lengths should fit within limits[1, 1000](not necessarily integer). Mutual comparing sides and angles of your polygon during the test will go with precision of10- 3.If there is no solution, print "No solution" (without the quotes).ExamplesInput8Output1.000 0.0007.000 0.0009.000 2.0009.000 3.0005.000 7.0003.000 7.0000.000 4.0000.000 1.000

processed.result:
Given an integer $n$ (where $3 \le n \le 100$), generate the coordinates of a convex polygon with $n$ vertices.  

The polygon must meet the following conditions:

* All angles of the polygon must be equal.
* All sides of the polygon must have different lengths.
* The coordinates of each vertex must be within the range $[-10^6, 10^6]$.
* The lengths of the sides must be within the range $[1, 1000]$.

If it is not possible to create such a polygon, print "No solution". 

Output the coordinates of the vertices in counter-clockwise order, with each vertex represented as  $(x_i, y_i)$.

Given a number, draw a polygon with that many sides where all sides are different lengths and all angles are equal. The coordinates of the corners of the polygon should be within a certain range. If it's impossible to draw such a polygon, say "No solution".
